item.title: Latin Lovers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[gallery spacing="small" columns="2" size="medium" type="masonry" ids="9999573,9999570"] A straightforward description of the warp and weft of Pradaâ€™s summer fabrics only partly illuminates what she seemed to be getting at. In basic terms, her collection was constructed within the confines of the silhouettes and items she has long made her own.
Neatly subsumed within that template was a subtle, tangential angle on the spectrum of boho-to-pervy references that have been rising this season.
Those forgiven, the cutting (inside-out seams), the phenomenal piecing of fabric, the appropriation of virginal, Victoriana, hippy-era necklines within curvy dresses, the coat of many patchworked colors: All articulated themes, which, in one way or another, have been rising all over the shows.  [gallery spacing="large" columns="5" ids="9999571,9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571"]

item.title: Sixties Fashion
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A half-century ago, Quant, who is celebrating her birthday today, was the most renowned fashion innovator in the world, promulgating her sixties mod aesthetic to millions of eager young women all over the globe.

Now they gleefully cast off their garter belts, their bullet bras, their nasty sheer stockings, and popped into Maryâ€™s minis, bloomers, baby dolls, shiny flat boots, see-through raincoats, removable plastic collars, crazy pjâ€™s, and cardigans long enoughâ€”but just barely!â€”to double as dresses. In The Rowâ€™s stately minimalist attire, Van der Wal looks worlds away from the femme fataleÂ she once played in VSâ€™s catalogs, but the new look suits her current status. [gallery type="slideshow" spacing="small" ids="9999571,9999572,9999573"] Contemporary examples of that beatnik staple, the dangling silver earring, are available in styles that include hammered orbs and double circles at Lori McLeanâ€™s lovely shop on Grove Street.
â€œEvolving in fashion has made me realize the power of images.â€
Well, everyone is grateful to Miuccia Prada for providing an experience and a sensation, at what must be massive cost, which aims to shake up emotions and prod the numbed intellect. Part of the ritual of going to a Prada show is the excited, nervy conversation that goes on as the audience spills onto the street afterward. [gallery spacing="small" columns="4" ids="9999570,9999571,9999572,9999573"] Thanks to the revival of brands like Paco Rabanne, chainmail has been given a whole new life since it made waves in the futuristic Space AgeÂ­â€“inspired collections of the 1960s. In The Rowâ€™s stately minimalist attire, Van der Wal looks worlds away from the femme fataleÂ she once played in VSâ€™s catalogs, but the new look suits her current status. Now they gleefully cast off their garter belts, their bullet bras, their nasty sheer stockings, and popped into Maryâ€™s minis, bloomers, baby dolls, shiny flat boots, see-through raincoats, removable plastic collars, crazy pjâ€™s, and cardigans long enoughâ€”but just barely!â€”to double as dresses.

item.title: Silvia Morres
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Silvia Morresâ€™s face is familiar to anyone who loves fashion. As a model, She hit every milestone, from working with the best photographers to serving as the face of major luxury brands like Chanel and Prada.

Words & Photographs byÂ Philipp Jelenska [gallery size="medium" columns="2" spacing="small" ids="9999571,9999572"] Thanks to the revival of brands like Paco Rabanne, chainmail has been given a whole new life since it made waves in the futuristic Space AgeÂ­â€“inspired collections of the 1960s. In The Rowâ€™s stately minimalist attire, Van der Wal looks worlds away from the femme fataleÂ she once played in VSâ€™s catalogs, but the new look suits her current status.
â€œEvolving in fashion has made me realize the power of images."
In the mid-2000s, â€œmodel off-dutyâ€ meant a standard uniform: A leather jacket, white tee or tank top, skinny jeans, and biker boots. It was slightly grunge, seriously no frills, and easy for pretty much anyone to pull off. Fast-forward almost a decade later, and thanks to the surge in social media, most models take every opportunity to taut their personal brand with attention-getting ensembles. [gallery spacing="small" type="masonry" size="large" ids="9999573,9999570,9999571"] And as the second age-appropriate model turned savvy businesswoman to grace The Rowâ€™s collectionsâ€”former model and present beauty entrepreneur Linda Rodin fronted their Pre-Fall 2014 lookbookâ€”Van der Wal represents much more than a â€œwhere are they nowâ€ moment. Now they gleefully cast off their garter belts, their bullet bras, their nasty sheer stockings, and popped into Maryâ€™s minis, bloomers, baby dolls, shiny flat boots, see-through raincoats, removable plastic collars, crazy pjâ€™s, and cardigans long enoughâ€”but just barely!â€”to double as dresses. In The Rowâ€™s stately minimalist attire, Van der Wal looks worlds away from the femme fataleÂ she once played in VSâ€™s catalogs, but the new look suits her current status.

I grew up in Staffordshire, England where I discovered my interest in photography at an early age. Later moved to London to pursue fashion photography full-time before making NYC my home in 2015. I have won a boatload of awards for my work, and Iâ€™m grateful for every single one of them, but Iâ€™ve always been unsure of whether I earned them or whether the jury was rigged.  Letâ€™s be friends. Better yet, letâ€™s swim the English Channel.

item.title: Casa Josephine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If you havenâ€™t done so already, itâ€™s time to rid your home of summery linens and seashells in favor of richer, warmer hues and textures. Not only will your home feel more seasonally appropriate, but it will also become a cozy haven as the colder weather approaches. While swapping out your white linens for a warmer comforter and cashmere throw are fairly obvious, creating the perfect reading nook or prepping your guest bedroom for the holidays may not be. Luckily, with help from a few of our design experts, weâ€™ve outlined six ways to seamlessly transition your home from summer to fall.

item.title: Penny Lane
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sisters Lily and Hopie Stockman are in the business of teaching others how to work with their hands. Aside from creating their own eye-catching, geometric printed textiles through their label Block Shop, the Stockmans also host a series of printing workshops at an enviable offsite studio and home in Joshua Tree, California. In a serene, well-appointed setting, visitors come to learn about the art of block printing, a craft that these sisters fell in love with back in 2010 after Lily met a master dyer in Jaipur while she was in art school there studying painting. She worked with the craftsman,Â Vijendra (Viju)Â Chhipa, on several pieces she then sent over to her sister who was back home. Hopie was so moved by the paintings that she traveled to meet Viju herself several months later and from there, they formed a textile business that would see all of its materials printed by Viju and his fellow local artisans. Wreaths are usually associated with Christmas and might make people think of overly craft-y, slightly tacky creations. But the true prime time for front door wreath hanging is arguably the fall. A welcoming garland ushers in the cozy sentiments of the season, and the creative varieties are seemingly endless. [gallery spacing="small" size="large" type="masonry" columns="2" ids="9999571,9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571,9999572,9999573"]

Look no further than the pouch as your evening bag of choice this fall. Itâ€™s the â€œwoke up like thisâ€ of accessoriesâ€”superchic but beautiful. Take an Etro silk embroidered pouch or even a rich velvet version by Ralph Lauren on the town. Go a little crazy, even, and treat yourself to The Rowâ€™s mink fur medicine cross-body.

â€œThe typical hard-shell miniature doesnâ€™t feel modern right now,â€ says Vogue.com Market Editor Chelsea Zalopany, adding that she usually veers more toward a â€œsatin pochette or a vintage coin purse,â€ possibly the key to achieving this Kate Mossâ€“in-the-â€™90s-meets-2016 look. And never fear, the pouch is more versatile than it may appearâ€”it pairs perfectly with everything from light-wash jeans and a T-shirt and slides, to a slinky little cocktail dress, to something even as dressy as black tie.

The modern feel of cotton

Much has been written about â€œstatement outerwear,â€ from blush peacoats to rainbow-striped furs and retro shearlings. The trend certainly isnâ€™t going anywhereâ€”we can thank Gucci for thatâ€”but thereâ€™s something to be said for a simple, decidedly unstylish coat.
â€œThe typical hard-shell miniature doesnâ€™t feel modern right nowâ€
Forgo the usual bouquet this fall for a hostess gift thatâ€™s a bit more unique and of the moment. Play up the flavors of fall with thoughtfully chosen wine, desserts, and even a lovely seasonal candle.If youâ€™re planning to spend a weekend away at a friendâ€™s home, bring a more substantial gift to show your gratitude for their hospitality. A welcoming garland ushers in the cozy sentiments of the season, and the creative varieties are seemingly endless. item.title: Buckle Up
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Look no further than the pouch as your evening bag of choice this fall. Itâ€™s the â€œwoke up like thisâ€ of accessoriesâ€”superchic but beautiful. Take an Etro silk embroidered pouch or even a rich velvet version by Ralph Lauren on the town.

Whether itâ€™s those vintage-inspired blue jeans, a trompe lâ€™oeil print, or a winter-white flare that youâ€™re after, read about all seven of our favorite new labels in the slideshow above. If you werenâ€™t already in the market for a new pair of jeans, youâ€™ll likely want oneâ€”or threeâ€”now. It wasnâ€™t so long ago that the idea of seeing jeans on the runway would have provided a serious shock.

THE SWEET RETURN OF LEGENADRY PIECES

Denim was strictly reserved for the weekend, not to be confused with haute ready-to-wearâ€”but that all changed within the space of a few years.Â This season alone there were denim trench coats, denim dresses, and no shortage of statement jeans.Â haring outfit-of-the-day selfies on Instagram, collecting the latest kicks, and showing up to events in everything from Kith streetwear to perfectly tailored tuxedos, the class of 2016 is already making its mark. Say goodbye to that clutch youâ€™ve been holding on to for the past three years. Itâ€™s time to pick up the pouch! Here, 14 luxe styles, all dressed up and ready to go. [gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" size="large" columns="2" ids="9999571,9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571"]

But what about the garden? Enter Jean Mus, one of the most highly regarded landscape architects operating out of the South of France. In his book, Private Gardens of the Mediterranean, Mus reveals a sampling of his most gorgeous workâ€”from traditionally groomed gardens of the French Riviera to the more country charms often found in Provence.

item.title: The Dreamers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In Tokyo, what you wear to the office is in many ways a group effort, and Japanâ€™s community of professionals dress in hive mind uniformity; the hordes of suited salarymen boarding the Chuo Line each morning is testament to that.

DressedUndressedâ€™s Spring collection riffed on the cityâ€™s community of hard workers and showed formal officewear that was reappropriated for the street, undoing a little of that desk-chained discipline. Whether a salaryman suit or a schoolgirlâ€™s sailor top, professional uniforms are crucial in Tokyo, explained Takeshi Kitazawa, who founded the brand with codesigner Emiko Sato in 2009. â€œI wanted to bend the rules a little,â€ Kitazawa said, the rules in this case being the many morals and manners expected in Japanese society. Although some pieces were more direct in the revamped workwear approach (a double-breasted black trenchcoat had an entire sleeve sliced off), the finer, wearable tweaks were more seductive: Billowing culottes were slit just above the knee, and silk, black laceâ€“trimmed chemises peeked out from oversize office shirts in cornflower blue. [gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" columns="2" size="large" ids="9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571,9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571,9999572"]

item.title: [Test] Image Alignment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to image alignment! The best way to demonstrate the ebb and flow of the various image positioning options is to nestle them snuggly among an ocean of words. Grab a paddle and letâ€™s get started.

Large Images â€“ No Captions

The rest of this paragraph is filler for the sake of seeing the text wrap around a left aligned image. As you can see there should be some space above, below, and to the left of the image. The text should not be creeping on the image. Creeping is just not right. Images need breathing room too. Let them speaklike you words. As you can see there should be some space above, below, and to the left of the image. The text should not be creeping on the image. Creeping is just not right. Images need breathing room too. Let them speak like you words. Donâ€™t let anyone else tell you differently. In just a bit here, you should see the text start to wrap below the left aligned image and settle in nicely. There should still be plenty of room and everything should be sitting pretty. Yeahâ€¦ Just like that. It never felt so good to be right.Let them do their jobs without any hassle from the text. item.title: Sharon Muir
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever walked down East Second Street? If the answer is yes, youâ€™ve likely been struck by the series of enchanting, gem-like shops known collectively as the John Derian Company. Carrying textiles, furniture, and many magical baubles, the storesâ€™ most renowned wares are undoubtedly the decoupage piecesâ€”made by Derian himself. And now, after almost three decadesâ€™ worth of production, a book detailing the prints behind these pieces is coming out next week. With vivid reproductionsâ€”and a foreword by Vogue Editor in Chief Anna Wintourâ€”it is truly a must-read. But what we really wanted to know after our own perusal was technical nitty-grittyâ€”decoupage 101, from where to shop for images to business words of wisdom. Here, John Derianâ€™s tips of the trade.
Â First off, how do you find the prints that you use?
Theyâ€™re mostly 18th- and 19th-centuryÂ prints from dealers and antique bookshops like The Old Print Shop on Lexington Avenueâ€”but 99 percent of the images come from instructive books. The funny, naive, and vintage ephemera are from a couple other more specific dealers and one flea market in New York. And, of course, whenever I am traveling I keep my eye open for paper goods. The subject matter I tend to work with documents all the beauty from the natural worldâ€”itâ€™s classic and timeless. I feel at peace in the outdoors, and I think that is somehow captured in these images.   [gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" size="full" ids="9999572,9999573,9999570"] And now, after almost three decadesâ€™ worth of production, a book detailing the prints behind these pieces is coming out next week. With vivid reproductionsâ€”and a foreword by Vogue Editor in Chief Anna Wintourâ€”it is truly a must-read. But what we really wanted to know after our own perusal was technical nitty-grittyâ€”decoupage 101, from where to shop for images to business words of wisdom. Here, John Derianâ€™s tips of the trade:

WHATâ€™S THE PROCESS LIKE AFTER SOURCING? FROM THE DESIGNS THEMSELVES TO GLASS APPLICATION? Â 

I collect prints throughout the year and then create a biannual collection for the four shows I doâ€”two in New York and two in Paris. I decide what I think will best show the beauty of the images I find: Will they work better larger or smaller? Would just a detail be enough? Then I mock up the pieces in my studio, and the team at my workshop piece it all together and I see what works. Most of the trays are a single layer of paper, with glue evenly applied on the surface of the image. Clear glass-blown trays from Virginia get placed on top, and the glue is moved around, leaving an even, cloudy film that dries clear. Then they get finishedâ€”painted with a gold border along the edges and felted. The 3-D pieces like cake pedestals and lamps have a similar but more labor-intensive process, involving anywhere from three to 60 individual pieces being cut and glued one at a time.

item.content:encoded:
[gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" columns="2" size="large" ids="9999572,9999573"] Look no further than the pouch as your evening bag of choice this fall. Itâ€™s the â€œwoke up like thisâ€ of accessoriesâ€”superchic but beautiful. Take an Etro silk embroidered pouch or even a rich velvet version by Ralph Lauren on the town. Go a little crazy, even, and treat yourself to The Rowâ€™s mink fur medicine cross-body. Shop all of the fleeces, puffers, and hoodies fashion editors are buying now in the slideshow above.Â And never fear, the pouch is more versatile than it may appearâ€”it pairs perfectly with everything from light-wash jeans and a T-shirt and slides, to a slinky little cocktail dress, to something even as dressy as black tie.
â€œThe typical hard-shell miniature doesnâ€™t feel modern right now compared to what the 60's brought upâ€
She usually veers more toward a â€œsatin pochette or a vintage coin purseâ€ possibly the key to achieving this Kate Mossâ€“in-the-â€™90s-meets-2016 look. And never fear, the pouch is more versatile than it may appearâ€”it pairs perfectly with everything from light-wash jeans and a T-shirt and slides, to a slinky little cocktail dress, to something even as dressy as black tie. On one hand, a basic coat often keeps you warmer than its fashion-y cousin (especially in February, when weâ€™re schlepping through a blizzard at Fashion Week), but it also lets you wear something super-loud underneath, like a neon sweater or a wildly impractical party dress. Shop all of the fleeces, puffers, and hoodies fashion editors are buying now in the slideshow above. [gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" size="full" ids="9999570,9999571,9999572"]

item.title: Ultima Parada
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Interior design can be a mystery to those who are not professionals. And of course, every designer has their own set of rules and ideas gleaned over decades of work.

When setting out to furnish your first home, there seems to be a never-ending list of items you need to buy that you didnâ€™t know you needed (i.e., a paper towel holder, towel hooks, et cetera). Before getting lost in the minutiae, outline some essentials that will make your new home feel complete, like a sofa or a great comforter. Larger items like a couch or bed frame are often more expensive, but if you spend a bit more now, youâ€™ll probably avoid having to replace it in just a few years.
In interior design, the happy marriage between architecture and decorating, the way you look at things makes a big difference between a pleasant solution and a transformative one.
Color is another element that deserves a second look. When designing for kids or pets, I think white upholstery is best. That sounds counterintuitive, but if you think about it, white can be bleached and colors canâ€™t; white tells you when it has to be cleaned. So why use fabrics that disguise dirt? Proportion is the relationship of parts to a wholeâ€”for example, the legs of a chair to its back. Scale is also the relationship of that chair to the room in which it sits. A designer should not be afraid to plant large pieces of furniture in a small room. [gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" size="full" ids="9999571,9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571,9999572"]

Take an Etro silk embroidered pouch or even a rich velvet version by Ralph Lauren on the town. Go a little crazy, even, and treat yourself to The Rowâ€™s mink fur medicine cross-body. â€œThe typical hard-shell miniature doesnâ€™t feel modern right now,â€ says Vogue.com Market Editor Chelsea Zalopany, adding that she usually veers more toward a â€œsatin pochette or a vintage coin purse,â€ possibly the key to achieving this Kate Mossâ€“in-the-â€™90s-meets-2016 look. And never fear, the pouch is more versatile than it may appearâ€”it pairs perfectly with everything from light-wash jeans and a T-shirt and slides, to a slinky little cocktail dress, to something even as dressy as black tie. item.title: In the dark
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Thereâ€™s a smart way to approach the herringbone and power suiting combination that, well, suits every kind of woman. Go completely classic and traditional in a blazer and straight-leg trousers.

Much has been written about â€œstatement outerwear,â€ from blush peacoats to rainbow-striped furs and retro shearlings. The trend certainly isnâ€™t going anywhereâ€”we can thank Gucci for thatâ€”but thereâ€™s something to be said for a simple, decidedly unstylish coat. Given the current political situation, â€œstayinâ€™ alive,â€ or rather staying sane, is a complicated proposition; it necessitates some life, and dress, hacks.Â The unlikely pairing seems tailor-made for a woman who looks incredibly chic yet not overly corporate, a woman who is confident and powerful and ready to take on anything. The unlikely pairing seems tailor-made for a woman who looks incredibly chic yet not overly corporate, a woman who is confident and powerful and ready to take on anything.Â Shop all of the fleeces, puffers, and hoodiesÂ Vogue.comÂ editors are buying now in the slideshow above.
Chalk it up to the Vetements effect, but weâ€™re on the hunt for plain parkas, quilted puffers, and rain jackets that are completely lacking in bells or whistles.
On one hand, a basic coat often keeps you warmer than its fashion-y cousin (especially in February, when weâ€™re schlepping through a blizzard at Fashion Week), but it also lets you wear something super-loud underneath, like a neon sweater or a wildly impractical party dress. Shop all of the fleeces, puffers, and hoodiesÂ Vogue.comÂ editors are buying now in the slideshow above. [gallery type="masonry" spacing="small" size="large" ids="9999572,9999573,9999570,9999571,9999572,9999573"]

item.title: Green Japan
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Fallâ€™s cooler temperatures mean itâ€™s time to swap out your summer-weight bedding for the heavy stuff, but if fall also means the start of allergy season, it might be time to change your bedding for a whole different reason.

After a recent trip to the allergist alerted me to the fact that my recent health woes were due to environmental allergens, I quickly realized that this seasonâ€™s bedroom refresh would have to be a bit more drastic than in years past. Wreaths are usually associated with Christmas and might make people think of overly craft-y, slightly tacky creations. But the true prime time for front door wreath hanging is arguably the fall. A welcoming garland ushers in the cozy sentiments of the season, and the creative varieties are seemingly endless.
â€œThe garden is the most beautiful kind of entertainment.â€ Jean Mus
Forgo the usual bouquet this fall for a hostess gift thatâ€™s a bit more unique and of the moment. Play up the flavors of fall with thoughtfully chosen wine, desserts, and even a lovely seasonal candle. If youâ€™re planning to spend a weekend away at a friendâ€™s home, bring a more substantial gift to show your gratitude for their hospitality. A fascinating new book, written by Lucinda Hawksley, examines this very questionâ€”but with an emphasis on one particular item: wallpaper. In the early to mid-19th century, many European countries produced wallpaper laced with arsenic.
Fall thorugh the spring
